newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Serbian government adopts 1997 draft budget-Tanjug.
newsitem.headline: Serbian government adopts 1997 draft budget-Tanjug.

text.p: The Serbian government on Wednesday adopted the republic's draft budget for 1997, with projected spending of more than 14 billion dinars, the official Tanjug news agency reported.
Accoding to Tanjug, the budget was projected at 14.060 billion dinars ($2.74 billion), but the agency gave no further details of the government's spending plans.
In November the government of Yugoslavia, which includes the republics of Serbia and Montenegro, adopted a 1997 draft budget of 9.238 billion dinars (1.86 billion).
The federal budget covers federal administration and defence costs, and Tanjug said the Serbian budget would cover "usual public expenditure."

"That includes state functions, social programmes and public services, while part of the budget will be used to fulfill legal obligations towards (unspecified) funds, and to stimulate production and agriculture," the agency quoted a government statement as saying.
"The budget volume is planned in line with consolidating the balance of Yugoslavia's public expenditure for next year and enables realising the aims of the 1997 economic policy."
According to official projections Yugoslavia's GDP is slated to rise 13 percent in 1997 to 103 billion dinars ($20.9 billion).
